00040 /**
00041  * @file
00042  * Functions for accessing memory and CSRs on Octeon when we are compiling
00043  * natively.
00044  *
00045  * <hr>$Revision: 38306 $<hr>
00046 */
00047 #ifndef __CVMX_ACCESS_NATIVE_H__
00048 #define __CVMX_ACCESS_NATIVE_H__
00049 #include "cvmx-asm.h"
00050 #ifdef  __cplusplus
00051 /* *INDENT-OFF* */
00052 extern "C" {
00053 /* *INDENT-ON* */
00054 #endif
00055 
00056 #ifndef CVMX_DEFAULT_ROOT_NODE
00057 #define CVMX_DEFAULT_ROOT_NODE 0
00058 #endif
00059 
00060 /**
00061  * Returns the Octeon processor ID.
00062  *
00063  * @return Octeon processor ID from COP0
00064  */
00065 static inline uint32_t cvmx_get_proc_id(void)
00066 {
00067 #ifdef CVMX_BUILD_FOR_LINUX_USER
00068     extern CVMX_SHARED uint32_t cvmx_app_init_processor_id;
00069     return cvmx_app_init_processor_id;
00070 #else
00071     uint32_t id;
00072     asm("mfc0 %0, $15,0":"=r"(id));
00073     return id;
00074 #endif
00075 }
00076 
00077 /**
00078  * Convert a memory pointer (void*) into a hardware compatable
00079  * memory address (uint64_t). Octeon hardware widgets don't
00080  * understand logical addresses.
00081  *
00082  * @param ptr    C style memory pointer
00083  * @return Hardware physical address
00084  *
00085  * NOTE: In simple executive this function will not return correct data in many
00086  * cases and should only be used for memory allocated using cvmx_bootmem_alloc.
00087  * Using this function on global variables or on memory allocated from the
00088  * stack will return incorrect addresses.
00089  *
00090  * NOTE: Internal use only
00091  */
00092 static inline __attribute__ ((__always_inline__))
00093 uint64_t __cvmx_ptr_to_phys_internal__(void *ptr)
00094 {
00095     if (CVMX_ENABLE_PARAMETER_CHECKING)
00096         cvmx_warn_if(ptr == NULL, "cvmx_ptr_to_phys() passed a NULL pointer\n");
00097 
00098     if (ptr == NULL)
00099         return 0;
00100 
00101 #ifdef CVMX_BUILD_FOR_UBOOT
00102     {
00103         uint64_t uboot_tlb_ptr_to_phys(void *ptr);
00104 
00105         if (((uint32_t) ptr) < 0x80000000) {
00106             /* Handle useg (unmapped due to ERL) here */
00107             return (CAST64(ptr) & 0x7FFFFFFF);
00108         } else if (((uint32_t) ptr) < 0xC0000000) {
00109             /* Here we handle KSEG0/KSEG1 _pointers_.  We know we are
00110              * dealing with 32 bit only values, so we treat them that way.
00111              *  Note that a cvmx_phys_to_ptr(cvmx_ptr_to_phys(X)) will not
00112              * return X in this case, but the physical address of the
00113              * KSEG0/KSEG1 address.
00114              */
00115             return (CAST64(ptr) & 0x1FFFFFFF);
00116         } else
00117             return (uboot_tlb_ptr_to_phys(ptr));    /* Should not get get here in !TLB case */
00118     }
00119 
00120 #endif
00121 
00122 #ifdef __linux__
00123     if (sizeof(void *) == 8) {
00124         /* We're running in 64 bit mode. Normally this means that we
00125          * can use 40 bits of address space (the hardware limit).
00126          * Unfortunately there is one case were we need to limit this
00127          * to 30 bits, sign extended 32 bit. Although these are 64 bits
00128          * wide, only 30 bits can be used
00129          */
00130         if ((CAST64(ptr) >> 62) == 3)
00131             return CAST64(ptr) & cvmx_build_mask(30);
00132         else
00133             return CAST64(ptr) & cvmx_build_mask(42);
00134     } else {
00135 #ifdef __KERNEL__
00136         return (long)(ptr) & 0x1fffffff;
00137 #else
00138         extern uint64_t linux_mem32_offset;
00139         if (cvmx_likely(ptr))
00140             return CAST64(ptr) - linux_mem32_offset;
00141         else
00142             return 0;
00143 #endif
00144     }
00145 #elif defined(_WRS_KERNEL)
00146     return (long)(ptr) & 0x7fffffff;
00147 #elif defined(VXWORKS_USER_MAPPINGS)
00148     /* This mapping mode is used in vxWorks 5.5 to support 2GB of ram. The
00149        2nd 256MB is mapped at 0x10000000 and the rest of memory is 1:1 */
00150     uint64_t address = (long)ptr;
00151     if (address & 0x80000000)
00152         return address & 0x1fffffff;    /* KSEG pointers directly map the lower 256MB and bootbus */
00153     else if ((address >= 0x10000000) && (address < 0x20000000))
00154         return address + 0x400000000ull;    /* 256MB-512MB is a virtual mapping for the 2nd 256MB */
00155     else
00156         return address; /* Looks to be a 1:1 mapped userspace pointer */
00157 #else
00158 # if CVMX_USE_1_TO_1_TLB_MAPPINGS
00159     /* We are assumung we're running the Simple Executive standalone.  In
00160      * this mode the TLB is setup to perform 1:1 mapping and 32 bit sign
00161      * extended addresses are never used.  Since we know all this, save the
00162      * masking cycles and do nothing.
00163      *
00164      * NOTE: This does the wrong thing in many cases and should only be used
00165      * for memory allocated using cvmx_bootmem_alloc.  Also, memory isn't
00166      * really 1:1 mapped.
00167      */
00168     if (CVMX_ENABLE_PARAMETER_CHECKING) {
00169         extern uint64_t __cvmx_max_1_to_1_mapped;
00170         cvmx_warn_if(CAST_ULL(CAST64(ptr)) >  __cvmx_max_1_to_1_mapped,
00171             "cvmx_ptr_to_phys() pointer out of range\n");
00172     }
00173 
00174     return CAST64(ptr);
00175 # else
00176     if (sizeof(void *) == 8) {
00177         /* Largest PABITS is 42 for CN78XX */
00178         if ((CAST64(ptr) >> 62) == 3)
00179             /* 32-bit compatibility address space */
00180             return CAST64(ptr) & cvmx_build_mask(30);
00181         else
00182             /* Assuming VA[62..63] == 0b10 := XKPHYS */
00183             return CAST64(ptr) & cvmx_build_mask(42);
00184         /* FIXME- many cases not handled here */
00185     } else
00186         return (long)(ptr) & 0x7fffffff;
00187 
00188 # endif
00189 #endif
00190 }
00191 
00192 /**
00193  * Convert a memory pointer (void*) into a hardware compatable
00194  * memory address (uint64_t). Octeon hardware widgets don't
00195  * understand logical addresses.
00196  *
00197  * @param ptr    C style memory pointer
00198  * @return Hardware physical address
00199  *
00200  * NOTE: For simple executive applications this should only be used for pointers
00201  * allocated using cvmx_bootmem_alloc.  Using this on pointers to global
00202  * variables or memory allocated on the stack may return incorrect values.
00203  * This function is much faster than cvmx_ptr_to_phys2() due to this assumption.
00204  */
00205 #ifndef __OPTIMIZE_SIZE__
00206 static inline __attribute__ ((__always_inline__))
00207 uint64_t cvmx_ptr_to_phys(void *ptr)
00208 {
00209     return __cvmx_ptr_to_phys_internal__(ptr);
00210 }
00211 #else
00212 uint64_t cvmx_ptr_to_phys(void *ptr);
00213 #endif
00214 
00215 /**
00216  * Convert a memory pointer (void*) into a hardware compatable
00217  * memory address (uint64_t). Octeon hardware widgets don't
00218  * understand logical addresses.
00219  *
00220  * @param ptr    C style memory pointer
00221  * @return Hardware physical address
00222  *
00223  * NOTE: This function should return the correct value in all cases.
00224  * NOTE: Internal use only
00225  */
00226 static inline __attribute__ ((__always_inline__))
00227 uint64_t __cvmx_ptr_to_phys2_internal__(void *ptr)
00228 {
00229     uint64_t eh_val;
00230     uint64_t lo;
00231     uint32_t pagemask;
00232     uint64_t asid;
00233     unsigned long offset;
00234     int index;
00235 
00236     if (CVMX_ENABLE_PARAMETER_CHECKING)
00237         cvmx_warn_if(ptr == NULL, "cvmx_ptr_to_phys() passed a NULL pointer\n");
00238 
00239     if (ptr == NULL)
00240         return 0;
00241 
00242     /* For KSEG0 and KSEG1 we can just map directly */
00243     switch (CAST64(ptr) & 0xFFFFFFFFE0000000ULL) {
00244     case 0xFFFFFFFF80000000ULL: /* KSEG0 */
00245     case 0xFFFFFFFFA0000000ULL: /* KSEG1 */
00246         return (long)ptr & 0x1FFFFFFF;
00247     }
00248     /* Check if XKPHYS, if so map directly */
00249     if ((sizeof(ptr) == 8) &&
00250             ((long)ptr & 0xC000000000000000ULL) == 0x8000000000000000ULL)
00251         return (long)ptr & 0x07FFFFFFFFFFFFFFULL;
00252 
00253     /* Clear low bits of address to properly form entry_hi */
00254     eh_val = (long)ptr & (~0ull << 13);
00255 
00256     /* Preserve ASID value */
00257     CVMX_MF_ENTRY_HIGH(asid);
00258     /* Load the virtual address, preserving the ASID value */
00259     CVMX_MT_ENTRY_HIGH(eh_val | (asid & 0xFF));
00260     CVMX_TLBP;          /* Probe the TLB */
00261     CVMX_MF_TLB_INDEX(index);   /* Get index */
00262 
00263     /* Return error if no entry found */
00264     if (index < 0)
00265         return 0xDEADBEEFDEADBEEFULL;
00266         /* return CAST64(ptr); */
00267 
00268     CVMX_TLBR;          /* Read matching TLB entry */
00269     CVMX_MF_PAGEMASK(pagemask); /* Get page size */
00270     pagemask |= 0x1fff;
00271     offset = (unsigned long)ptr & pagemask;
00272     /* Figure out which entry based on offset */
00273     if (offset <= (pagemask >> 1))
00274         CVMX_MF_ENTRY_LO_0(lo);
00275     else
00276         CVMX_MF_ENTRY_LO_1(lo);
00277 
00278     /* Get physical page address */
00279     lo = (lo & ~0x3f) << 6;
00280 
00281     return lo + ((unsigned long)ptr & (pagemask >> 1));
00282 }
00283 
00284 /**
00285  * Convert a memory pointer (void *) into a hardware compatible memory address
00286  * (uint64_t).  Octeon hardware widgets don't understand logical addresses.
00287  *
00288  * @param ptr   C style memory pointer
00289  * @return  Hardware physical address
00290  *
00291  * NOTE: This function should return the correct value in all cases.
00292  */
00293 #ifndef __OPTIMIZE_SIZE__
00294 static inline __attribute__ ((__always_inline__))
00295 uint64_t cvmx_ptr_to_phys2(void *ptr)
00296 {
00297     return __cvmx_ptr_to_phys2_internal__(ptr);
00298 }
00299 #else
00300 uint64_t cvmx_ptr_to_phys2(void *ptr);
00301 #endif
00302 
00303 /**
00304  * Convert a hardware physical address (uint64_t) into a
00305  * memory pointer (void *).
00306  *
00307  * @param physical_address
00308  *               Hardware physical address to memory
00309  * @return Pointer to memory
00310  *
00311  * NOTE: Internal use only
00312  */
00313 static inline __attribute__ ((__always_inline__))
00314 void *__cvmx_phys_to_ptr_internal__(uint64_t physical_address)
00315 {
00316     if (CVMX_ENABLE_PARAMETER_CHECKING)
00317         cvmx_warn_if(physical_address == 0, "cvmx_phys_to_ptr() passed a zero address\n");
00318 
00319 #ifdef CVMX_BUILD_FOR_UBOOT
00320 
00321     /* U-boot is a special case, as it is running in 32 bit mode, using the TLB to map code/data
00322      ** which can have a physical address above the 32 bit address space.  1-1 mappings are used
00323      ** to allow the low 2 GBytes to be accessed as in error level.
00324      **
00325      ** NOTE:  This conversion can cause problems in u-boot, as users may want to enter addresses
00326      ** like 0xBFC00000 (kseg1 boot bus address), which is a valid 64 bit physical address,
00327      ** but is likely intended to be a boot bus address. */
00328 
00329     if (physical_address < 0x80000000) {
00330         /* Handle useg here.  ERL is set, so useg is unmapped.  This is the only physical
00331          ** address range that is directly addressable by u-boot. */
00332         return CASTPTR(void, physical_address);
00333     } else {
00334         DECLARE_GLOBAL_DATA_PTR;
00335         extern char uboot_start;
00336         /* Above 0x80000000 we can only support one case - a physical address
00337          ** that is mapped for u-boot code/data.  We check against the u-boot mem range,
00338          ** and return NULL if it is out of this range.
00339          */
00340         if (physical_address >= gd->bd->bi_uboot_ram_addr && physical_address < gd->bd->bi_uboot_ram_addr + gd->bd->bi_uboot_ram_used_size) {
00341             return ((char *)&uboot_start + (physical_address - gd->bd->bi_uboot_ram_addr));
00342         } else
00343             return (NULL);
00344     }
00345 
00346     if (physical_address >= 0x80000000)
00347         return NULL;
00348 #endif
00349 #ifdef __linux__
00350     if (sizeof(void *) == 8) {
00351         /* Just set the top bit, avoiding any TLB uglyness */
00352         return CASTPTR(void, CVMX_ADD_SEG(CVMX_MIPS_SPACE_XKPHYS, physical_address));
00353     } else {
00354         extern uint64_t linux_mem32_offset;
00355         if (cvmx_likely(physical_address))
00356             return CASTPTR(void, physical_address + linux_mem32_offset);
00357         else
00358             return NULL;
00359     }
00360 #elif defined(_WRS_KERNEL)
00361     return CASTPTR(void, CVMX_ADD_SEG32(CVMX_MIPS32_SPACE_KSEG0, physical_address));
00362 #elif defined(VXWORKS_USER_MAPPINGS)
00363     /* This mapping mode is used in vxWorks 5.5 to support 2GB of ram. The
00364        2nd 256MB is mapped at 0x10000000 and the rest of memory is 1:1 */
00365     if ((physical_address >= 0x10000000) && (physical_address < 0x20000000))
00366         return CASTPTR(void, CVMX_ADD_SEG32(CVMX_MIPS32_SPACE_KSEG0, physical_address));
00367     else if ((OCTEON_IS_MODEL(OCTEON_CN3XXX) || OCTEON_IS_MODEL(OCTEON_CN5XXX))
00368          && (physical_address >= 0x410000000ull)
00369          && (physical_address < 0x420000000ull))
00370         return CASTPTR(void, physical_address - 0x400000000ull);
00371     else
00372         return CASTPTR(void, physical_address);
00373 #else
00374 
00375 #if CVMX_USE_1_TO_1_TLB_MAPPINGS
00376     /* We are assumung we're running the Simple Executive standalone. In this
00377        mode the TLB is setup to perform 1:1 mapping and 32 bit sign extended
00378        addresses are never used. Since we know all this, save bit insert
00379        cycles and do nothing */
00380     if (CVMX_ENABLE_PARAMETER_CHECKING) {
00381         extern uint64_t __cvmx_max_1_to_1_mapped;
00382         cvmx_warn_if(physical_address >  __cvmx_max_1_to_1_mapped,
00383             "cvmx_phys_to_ptr() pointer out of range\n");
00384     }
00385 
00386     return CASTPTR(void, physical_address);
00387 #else
00388     if (!physical_address)
00389         return NULL;
00390     /* Set the XKPHYS/KSEG0 bit as appropriate based on ABI */
00391     if (sizeof(void *) == 8)
00392         return CASTPTR(void, CVMX_ADD_SEG(CVMX_MIPS_SPACE_XKPHYS, physical_address));
00393     else
00394         return CASTPTR(void, CVMX_ADD_SEG32(CVMX_MIPS32_SPACE_KSEG0, physical_address));
00395 
00396 #endif
00397 
00398 #endif
00399 }
00400 
00401 /**
00402  * Convert a hardware physical address (uint64_t) into a
00403  * memory pointer (void *).
00404  *
00405  * @param physical_address
00406  *               Hardware physical address to memory
00407  * @return Pointer to memory
00408  *
00409  * NOTE: this function is defined as non-static inline in
00410  * U-Boot's lib_octeon.c.
00411  */
00412 #ifndef __OPTIMIZE_SIZE__
00413 static inline __attribute__ ((__always_inline__))
00414 void *cvmx_phys_to_ptr(uint64_t physical_address)
00415 {
00416     return __cvmx_phys_to_ptr_internal__(physical_address);
00417 }
00418 #else
00419 void *cvmx_phys_to_ptr(uint64_t physical_address);
00420 #endif
00421 
00422 /* The following #if controls the definition of the macro
00423     CVMX_BUILD_WRITE64. This macro is used to build a store operation to
00424     a full 64bit address. With a 64bit ABI, this can be done with a simple
00425     pointer access. 32bit ABIs require more complicated assembly */
00426 #if defined(CVMX_ABI_N64) || defined(CVMX_ABI_EABI)
00427 
00428 /* We have a full 64bit ABI. Writing to a 64bit address can be done with
00429     a simple volatile pointer */
00430 #define CVMX_BUILD_WRITE64(TYPE, ST)                                    \
00431 static inline void cvmx_write64_##TYPE(uint64_t addr, TYPE##_t val)     \
00432 {                                                                       \
00433     *CASTPTR(volatile TYPE##_t, addr) = val;                            \
00434 }
00435 
00436 #elif defined(CVMX_ABI_N32)
00437 
00438 /* The N32 ABI passes all 64bit quantities in a single register, so it is
00439     possible to use the arguments directly. We have to use inline assembly
00440     for the actual store since a pointer would truncate the address */
00441 #define CVMX_BUILD_WRITE64(TYPE, ST)                                    \
00442 static inline void cvmx_write64_##TYPE(uint64_t addr, TYPE##_t val)     \
00443 {                                                                       \
00444     asm volatile (ST " %[v], 0(%[c])" ::[v] "r" (val), [c] "r" (addr)); \
00445 }
00446 
00447 #elif defined(CVMX_ABI_O32)
00448 
00449 #ifdef __KERNEL__
00450 #define CVMX_BUILD_WRITE64(TYPE, LT) extern void cvmx_write64_##TYPE(uint64_t csr_addr, TYPE##_t val);
00451 #else
00452 
00453 /* Ok, now the ugly stuff starts. O32 splits 64bit quantities into two
00454     separate registers. Assembly must be used to put them back together
00455     before they're used. What should be a simple store becomes a
00456     convoluted mess of shifts and ors */
00457 #define CVMX_BUILD_WRITE64(TYPE, ST)                                    \
00458 static inline void cvmx_write64_##TYPE(uint64_t csr_addr, TYPE##_t val) \
00459 {                                                                       \
00460     if (sizeof(TYPE##_t) == 8)                                          \
00461     {                                                                   \
00462         uint32_t csr_addrh = csr_addr>>32;                              \
00463         uint32_t csr_addrl = csr_addr;                                  \
00464         uint32_t valh = (uint64_t)val>>32;                              \
00465         uint32_t vall = val;                                            \
00466         uint32_t tmp1;                                                  \
00467         uint32_t tmp2;                                                  \
00468         uint32_t tmp3;                                                  \
00469                                                                         \
00470         asm volatile (                                                  \
00471             ".set push\n"                                             \
00472             ".set mips64\n"                                             \
00473             "dsll   %[tmp1], %[valh], 32\n"                             \
00474             "dsll   %[tmp2], %[csrh], 32\n"                             \
00475             "dsll   %[tmp3], %[vall], 32\n"                             \
00476             "dsrl   %[tmp3], %[tmp3], 32\n"                             \
00477             "or     %[tmp1], %[tmp1], %[tmp3]\n"                        \
00478             "dsll   %[tmp3], %[csrl], 32\n"                             \
00479             "dsrl   %[tmp3], %[tmp3], 32\n"                             \
00480             "or     %[tmp2], %[tmp2], %[tmp3]\n"                        \
00481             ST "    %[tmp1], 0(%[tmp2])\n"                              \
00482             ".set pop\n"                                             \
00483             : [tmp1] "=&r" (tmp1), [tmp2] "=&r" (tmp2), [tmp3] "=&r" (tmp3)\
00484             : [valh] "r" (valh), [vall] "r" (vall),                     \
00485               [csrh] "r" (csr_addrh), [csrl] "r" (csr_addrl)            \
00486         );                                                              \
00487     }                                                                   \
00488     else                                                                \
00489     {                                                                   \
00490         uint32_t csr_addrh = csr_addr>>32;                              \
00491         uint32_t csr_addrl = csr_addr;                                  \
00492         uint32_t tmp1;                                                  \
00493         uint32_t tmp2;                                                  \
00494                                                                         \
00495         asm volatile (                                                  \
00496             ".set push\n"                                             \
00497             ".set mips64\n"                                             \
00498             "dsll   %[tmp1], %[csrh], 32\n"                             \
00499             "dsll   %[tmp2], %[csrl], 32\n"                             \
00500             "dsrl   %[tmp2], %[tmp2], 32\n"                             \
00501             "or     %[tmp1], %[tmp1], %[tmp2]\n"                        \
00502             ST "    %[val], 0(%[tmp1])\n"                               \
00503             ".set pop\n"                                             \
00504             : [tmp1] "=&r" (tmp1), [tmp2] "=&r" (tmp2)                  \
00505             : [val] "r" (val), [csrh] "r" (csr_addrh),                  \
00506               [csrl] "r" (csr_addrl)                                    \
00507         );                                                              \
00508     }                                                                   \
00509 }
00510 
00511 #endif
00512 
00513 #else
00514 
00515 /* cvmx-abi.h didn't recognize the ABI. Force the compile to fail. */
00516 #error: Unsupported ABI
00517 
00518 #endif
00519 
00520 /* The following #if controls the definition of the macro
00521     CVMX_BUILD_READ64. This macro is used to build a load operation from
00522     a full 64bit address. With a 64bit ABI, this can be done with a simple
00523     pointer access. 32bit ABIs require more complicated assembly */
00524 #if defined(CVMX_ABI_N64) || defined(CVMX_ABI_EABI)
00525 
00526 /* We have a full 64bit ABI. Writing to a 64bit address can be done with
00527     a simple volatile pointer */
00528 #define CVMX_BUILD_READ64(TYPE, LT)                                     \
00529 static inline TYPE##_t cvmx_read64_##TYPE(uint64_t addr)                \
00530 {                                                                       \
00531     return *CASTPTR(volatile TYPE##_t, addr);                           \
00532 }
00533 
00534 #elif defined(CVMX_ABI_N32)
00535 
00536 /* The N32 ABI passes all 64bit quantities in a single register, so it is
00537     possible to use the arguments directly. We have to use inline assembly
00538     for the actual store since a pointer would truncate the address */
00539 #define CVMX_BUILD_READ64(TYPE, LT)                                     \
00540 static inline TYPE##_t cvmx_read64_##TYPE(uint64_t addr)                \
00541 {                                                                       \
00542     TYPE##_t val;                                                       \
00543     asm volatile (LT " %[v], 0(%[c])": [v] "=r" (val) : [c] "r" (addr));\
00544     return val;                                                         \
00545 }
00546 
00547 #elif defined(CVMX_ABI_O32)
00548 
00549 #ifdef __KERNEL__
00550 #define CVMX_BUILD_READ64(TYPE, LT) extern TYPE##_t cvmx_read64_##TYPE(uint64_t csr_addr);
00551 #else
00552 
00553 /* Ok, now the ugly stuff starts. O32 splits 64bit quantities into two
00554     separate registers. Assembly must be used to put them back together
00555     before they're used. What should be a simple load becomes a
00556     convoluted mess of shifts and ors */
00557 #define CVMX_BUILD_READ64(TYPE, LT)                                     \
00558 static inline TYPE##_t cvmx_read64_##TYPE(uint64_t csr_addr)            \
00559 {                                                                       \
00560     if (sizeof(TYPE##_t) == 8)                                          \
00561     {                                                                   \
00562         uint32_t csr_addrh = csr_addr>>32;                              \
00563         uint32_t csr_addrl = csr_addr;                                  \
00564         uint32_t valh;                                                  \
00565         uint32_t vall;                                                  \
00566                                                                         \
00567         asm volatile (                                                  \
00568             ".set push\n"                                               \
00569             ".set mips64\n"                                             \
00570             "dsll   %[valh], %[csrh], 32\n"                             \
00571             "dsll   %[vall], %[csrl], 32\n"                             \
00572             "dsrl   %[vall], %[vall], 32\n"                             \
00573             "or     %[valh], %[valh], %[vall]\n"                        \
00574             LT "    %[vall], 0(%[valh])\n"                              \
00575             "dsrl   %[valh], %[vall], 32\n"                             \
00576             "sll    %[vall], 0\n"                                       \
00577             "sll    %[valh], 0\n"                                       \
00578             ".set pop\n"                                                \
00579             : [valh] "=&r" (valh), [vall] "=&r" (vall)                  \
00580             : [csrh] "r" (csr_addrh), [csrl] "r" (csr_addrl)            \
00581         );                                                              \
00582         return ((uint64_t)valh<<32) | vall;                             \
00583     }                                                                   \
00584     else                                                                \
00585     {                                                                   \
00586         uint32_t csr_addrh = csr_addr>>32;                              \
00587         uint32_t csr_addrl = csr_addr;                                  \
00588         TYPE##_t val;                                                   \
00589         uint32_t tmp;                                                   \
00590                                                                         \
00591         asm volatile (                                                  \
00592             ".set push\n"                                             \
00593             ".set mips64\n"                                             \
00594             "dsll   %[val], %[csrh], 32\n"                              \
00595             "dsll   %[tmp], %[csrl], 32\n"                              \
00596             "dsrl   %[tmp], %[tmp], 32\n"                               \
00597             "or     %[val], %[val], %[tmp]\n"                           \
00598             LT "    %[val], 0(%[val])\n"                                \
00599             ".set pop\n"                                             \
00600             : [val] "=&r" (val), [tmp] "=&r" (tmp)                      \
00601             : [csrh] "r" (csr_addrh), [csrl] "r" (csr_addrl)            \
00602         );                                                              \
00603         return val;                                                     \
00604     }                                                                   \
00605 }
00606 
00607 #endif /* __KERNEL__ */
00608 
00609 #else
00610 
00611 /* cvmx-abi.h didn't recognize the ABI. Force the compile to fail. */
00612 #error: Unsupported ABI
00613 
00614 #endif
00615 
00616 /* The following defines 8 functions for writing to a 64bit address. Each
00617     takes two arguments, the address and the value to write.
00618     cvmx_write64_int64      cvmx_write64_uint64
00619     cvmx_write64_int32      cvmx_write64_uint32
00620     cvmx_write64_int16      cvmx_write64_uint16
00621     cvmx_write64_int8       cvmx_write64_uint8 */
00622 CVMX_BUILD_WRITE64(int64, "sd");
00623 CVMX_BUILD_WRITE64(int32, "sw");
00624 CVMX_BUILD_WRITE64(int16, "sh");
00625 CVMX_BUILD_WRITE64(int8, "sb");
00626 CVMX_BUILD_WRITE64(uint64, "sd");
00627 CVMX_BUILD_WRITE64(uint32, "sw");
00628 CVMX_BUILD_WRITE64(uint16, "sh");
00629 CVMX_BUILD_WRITE64(uint8, "sb");
00630 
00631 /* The following defines 8 functions for reading from a 64bit address. Each
00632     takes the address as the only argument
00633     cvmx_read64_int64       cvmx_read64_uint64
00634     cvmx_read64_int32       cvmx_read64_uint32
00635     cvmx_read64_int16       cvmx_read64_uint16
00636     cvmx_read64_int8        cvmx_read64_uint8 */
00637 CVMX_BUILD_READ64(int64, "ld");
00638 CVMX_BUILD_READ64(int32, "lw");
00639 CVMX_BUILD_READ64(int16, "lh");
00640 CVMX_BUILD_READ64(int8, "lb");
00641 CVMX_BUILD_READ64(uint64, "ld");
00642 CVMX_BUILD_READ64(uint32, "lw");
00643 CVMX_BUILD_READ64(uint16, "lhu");
00644 CVMX_BUILD_READ64(uint8, "lbu");
00645 
00646 /**
00647  * Write to a CSR address on the specified node
00648  *
00649  * @param node      OCTEON node number
00650  * @param csr_addr  address to write to
00651  * @param val       value to write
00652  *
00653  * NOTE: If the NODE is already encoded in csr_addr then the node in the address
00654  * will be overwritten with the node parameter.
00655  */
00656 static inline void cvmx_write_csr_node(uint64_t node, uint64_t csr_addr,
00657                        uint64_t val)
00658 {
00659     uint64_t node_addr;
00660     uint64_t composite_csr_addr;
00661 
00662     node_addr = (node & CVMX_NODE_MASK) << CVMX_NODE_IO_SHIFT;
00663     composite_csr_addr = (csr_addr & ~CVMX_NODE_IO_MASK) | node_addr;
00664 
00665     cvmx_write64_uint64(composite_csr_addr, val);
00666     /*
00667      * Perform an immediate read after every write to an RSL
00668      * register to force the write to complete. It doesn't matter
00669      * what RSL read we do, so we choose CVMX_MIO_BOOT_BIST_STAT
00670      * on the same node because it is fast and harmless
00671      */
00672     if (((csr_addr >> 40) & 0x7ffff) == (0x118)) {
00673         cvmx_read64_uint64(CVMX_MIO_BOOT_BIST_STAT | node_addr);
00674     }
00675 }
00676 
00677 /**
00678  * Write to a CSR address
00679  *
00680  * @param csr_addr  address to write to
00681  * @param val       value to write
00682  */
00683 static inline void cvmx_write_csr(uint64_t csr_addr, uint64_t val)
00684 {
00685     cvmx_write64_uint64(csr_addr, val);
00686 
00687     /* Perform an immediate read after every write to an RSL register to force
00688        the write to complete. It doesn't matter what RSL read we do, so we
00689        choose CVMX_MIO_BOOT_BIST_STAT because it is fast and harmless */
00690     if (((csr_addr >> 40) & 0x7ffff) == (0x118))
00691         cvmx_read64_uint64(CVMX_MIO_BOOT_BIST_STAT);
00692 }
00693 
00694 /**
00695  * Perform a 64-bit write to an IO address
00696  *
00697  * @param io_addr   I/O address to write to
00698  * @param val       64-bit value to write
00699  */
00700 static inline void cvmx_write_io(uint64_t io_addr, uint64_t val)
00701 {
00702     cvmx_write64_uint64(io_addr, val);
00703 }
00704 
00705 /**
00706  * Read from a CSR address on the specified node
00707  *
00708  * @param node      node to read from
00709  * @param csr_addr  address of CSR to read from
00710  *
00711  * @returns value of CSR address
00712  *
00713  * NOTE: If the NODE is already encoded in csr_addr then the node in the address
00714  * will be overwritten with the node parameter.
00715  */
00716 static inline uint64_t cvmx_read_csr_node(uint64_t node, uint64_t csr_addr)
00717 {
00718     uint64_t node_addr;
00719 
00720     node_addr = (csr_addr & ~CVMX_NODE_IO_MASK) |
00721                 (node & CVMX_NODE_MASK) << CVMX_NODE_IO_SHIFT;
00722     return cvmx_read_csr(node_addr);
00723 }
00724 
00725 /**
00726  * Read from a CSR address
00727  *
00728  * @param csr_addr  address of CSR to read from
00729  *
00730  * @returns value of CSR address
00731  */
00732 static inline uint64_t cvmx_read_csr(uint64_t csr_addr)
00733 {
00734     return cvmx_read64_uint64(csr_addr);
00735 }
00736 
00737 static inline void cvmx_send_single(uint64_t data)
00738 {
00739     cvmx_write64_uint64(CVMX_IOBDMA_ORDERED_IO_ADDR, data);
00740 }
00741 
00742 /**
00743  * Perform a background I/O read operation
00744  *
00745  * @param node      node to read from
00746  * @param scraddr   Starting location where the core puts the result
00747  *          0xFFFFFFFFFFFF8000 + (8 * srcaddr)
00748  * @param csr_addr  Address of CSR to read
00749  */
00750 static inline void cvmx_read_csr_async_node(uint8_t node, uint64_t scraddr,
00751                         uint64_t csr_addr)
00752 {
00753     uint64_t node_addr;
00754     if (!octeon_has_feature(OCTEON_FEATURE_MULTINODE)) {
00755         //printf("Resetting node(%d) to 0\n", node);
00756         node = 0;
00757     }
00758     node_addr = csr_addr | (((uint64_t)node & CVMX_NODE_MASK) << CVMX_NODE_IO_SHIFT);
00759     cvmx_read_csr_async(scraddr, node_addr);
00760 }
00761 
00762 /**
00763  * Perform a background I/O read operation
00764  *
00765  * @param scraddr   Starting location where the core puts the result
00766  *          0xFFFFFFFFFFFF8000 + (8 * srcaddr)
00767  * @param csr_addr  Address of CSR to read
00768  */
00769 static inline void cvmx_read_csr_async(uint64_t scraddr, uint64_t csr_addr)
00770 {
00771     union {
00772         uint64_t u64;
00773         struct {
00774             uint64_t scraddr:8;
00775             uint64_t len:8;
00776             uint64_t addr:48;
00777         } s;
00778     } addr;
00779     addr.u64 = csr_addr;
00780     addr.s.scraddr = scraddr >> 3;
00781     addr.s.len = 1;
00782     cvmx_send_single(addr.u64);
00783 }
00784 
00785 /**
00786  * Number of the Core on which the program is currently running.
00787  *
00788  * @return core number
00789  */
00790 static inline unsigned int cvmx_get_core_num(void)
00791 {
00792     unsigned int core_num;
00793     CVMX_RDHWRNV(core_num, 0);
00794     return core_num;
00795 }
00796 
00797 /**
00798  * Number of the node on which the program is currently running.
00799  *
00800  * @return current node number
00801  */
00802 static inline unsigned int cvmx_get_node_num(void)
00803 {
00804     unsigned int core_num;
00805     CVMX_RDHWRNV(core_num, 0);
00806     return (core_num >> CVMX_NODE_NO_SHIFT) & CVMX_NODE_MASK;
00807 }
00808 
00809 /**
00810  * Node-local number of the core on which the program is currently running.
00811  *
00812  * @return core number on local node
00813  */
00814 static inline unsigned int cvmx_get_local_core_num(void)
00815 {
00816     unsigned int core_num, core_mask;
00817     CVMX_RDHWRNV(core_num, 0);
00818     /* note that MAX_CORES may not be power of 2 */
00819     core_mask = (1 << CVMX_NODE_NO_SHIFT) -1;
00820     return core_num & core_mask;
00821 }
00822 
00823 /**
00824  * Returns the number of bits set in the provided value.
00825  * Simple wrapper for POP instruction.
00826  *
00827  * @param val    32 bit value to count set bits in
00828  *
00829  * @return Number of bits set
00830  */
00831 static inline uint32_t cvmx_pop(uint32_t val)
00832 {
00833     uint32_t pop;
00834     CVMX_POP(pop, val);
00835     return pop;
00836 }
00837 
00838 /**
00839  * Returns the number of bits set in the provided value.
00840  * Simple wrapper for DPOP instruction.
00841  *
00842  * @param val    64 bit value to count set bits in
00843  *
00844  * @return Number of bits set
00845  */
00846 static inline int cvmx_dpop(uint64_t val)
00847 {
00848     int pop;
00849     CVMX_DPOP(pop, val);
00850     return pop;
00851 }

00853 /**
00854  * @deprecated
00855  * Provide current cycle counter as a return value. Deprecated, use
00856  * cvmx_clock_get_count(CVMX_CLOCK_CORE) to get cycle counter.
00857  *
00858  * @return current cycle counter
00859  */
00860 static inline uint64_t cvmx_get_cycle(void)
00861 {
00862     return cvmx_clock_get_count(CVMX_CLOCK_CORE);
00863 }

00865 /**
00866  * @deprecated
00867  * Reads a chip global cycle counter.  This counts SCLK cycles since
00868  * chip reset.  The counter is 64 bit. This function is deprecated as the rate
00869  * of the global cycle counter is different between Octeon+ and Octeon2, use
00870  * cvmx_clock_get_count(CVMX_CLOCK_SCLK) instead. For Octeon2, the clock rate
00871  * of SCLK may be differnet than the core clock.
00872  *
00873  * @return Global chip cycle count since chip reset.
00874  */
00875 static inline uint64_t cvmx_get_cycle_global(void)
00876 {
00877     return cvmx_clock_get_count(CVMX_CLOCK_IPD);
00878 }
00879 static inline uint64_t cvmx_get_cycle_global(void) __attribute__((deprecated));

00881 /**
00882  * Wait for the specified number of core clock cycles
00883  *
00884  * @param cycles
00885  */
00886 static inline void cvmx_wait(uint64_t cycles)
00887 {
00888     uint64_t done = cvmx_get_cycle() + cycles;
00889 
00890     while (cvmx_get_cycle() < done) {
00891         /* Spin */
00892     }
00893 }
00894 
00895 static inline void __cvmx_wait_usec_internal__(uint64_t usec)
00896 {
00897     uint64_t done = cvmx_get_cycle() + usec * cvmx_clock_get_rate(CVMX_CLOCK_CORE) / 1000000;
00898     while (cvmx_get_cycle() < done) {
00899         /* Spin */
00900     }
00901 }
00902 
00903 /**
00904  * Wait for the specified number of micro seconds
00905  *
00906  * @param usec   micro seconds to wait
00907  *
00908  * NOTE: this function is defined as non-static inline in
00909  * U-Boot's lib_octeon.c.
00910  */
00911 #ifndef __OPTIMIZE_SIZE__
00912 static inline void cvmx_wait_usec(uint64_t usec)
00913 {
00914     __cvmx_wait_usec_internal__(usec);
00915 }
00916 #else
00917 void cvmx_wait_usec(uint64_t usec);
00918 #endif

00920 /**
00921  * Wait for the specified number of io clock cycles
00922  *
00923  * @param cycles
00924  */
00925 static inline void cvmx_wait_io(uint64_t cycles)
00926 {
00927     uint64_t done = cvmx_clock_get_count(CVMX_CLOCK_SCLK) + cycles;
00928 
00929     while (cvmx_clock_get_count(CVMX_CLOCK_SCLK) < done) {
00930         /* Spin */
00931     }
00932 }

00934 /**
00935  * Perform a soft reset of Octeon
00936  *
00937  * @return
00938  */
00939 static inline void cvmx_reset_octeon_node(uint8_t node)
00940 {
00941     cvmx_ciu_soft_rst_t ciu_soft_rst;
00942     ciu_soft_rst.u64 = 0;
00943     ciu_soft_rst.s.soft_rst = 1;
00944     if (OCTEON_IS_OCTEON3())
00945         cvmx_write_csr_node(node, CVMX_RST_SOFT_RST, ciu_soft_rst.u64);
00946     else
00947         cvmx_write_csr_node(node, CVMX_CIU_SOFT_RST, ciu_soft_rst.u64);
00948 }
00949 
00950 /**
00951  * Perform a soft reset of Octeon
00952  *
00953  * @return
00954  */
00955 static inline void cvmx_reset_octeon(void)
00956 {
00957     cvmx_ciu_soft_rst_t ciu_soft_rst;
00958     ciu_soft_rst.u64 = 0;
00959     ciu_soft_rst.s.soft_rst = 1;
00960     if (OCTEON_IS_OCTEON3())
00961         cvmx_write_csr(CVMX_RST_SOFT_RST, ciu_soft_rst.u64);
00962     else
00963         cvmx_write_csr(CVMX_CIU_SOFT_RST, ciu_soft_rst.u64);
00964 }
00965 
00966 /**
00967  * Read a byte of fuse data
00968  * @param node      node to read from
00969  * @param byte_addr address to read
00970  *
00971  * @return fuse value: 0 or 1
00972  */
00973 static inline uint8_t cvmx_fuse_read_byte_node(uint8_t node, int byte_addr)
00974 {
00975     cvmx_mio_fus_rcmd_t read_cmd;
00976 
00977     read_cmd.u64 = 0;
00978     read_cmd.s.addr = byte_addr;
00979     read_cmd.s.pend = 1;
00980     cvmx_write_csr_node(node, CVMX_MIO_FUS_RCMD, read_cmd.u64);
00981     while ((read_cmd.u64 = cvmx_read_csr_node(node, CVMX_MIO_FUS_RCMD))
00982            && read_cmd.s.pend)
00983         ;
00984     return read_cmd.s.dat;
00985 }
00986 
00987 /**
00988  * Read a byte of fuse data
00989  * @param byte_addr   address to read
00990  *
00991  * @return fuse value: 0 or 1
00992  */
00993 static inline uint8_t cvmx_fuse_read_byte(int byte_addr)
00994 {
00995     cvmx_mio_fus_rcmd_t read_cmd;
00996 
00997     read_cmd.u64 = 0;
00998     read_cmd.s.addr = byte_addr;
00999     read_cmd.s.pend = 1;
01000     cvmx_write_csr(CVMX_MIO_FUS_RCMD, read_cmd.u64);
01001     while ((read_cmd.u64 = cvmx_read_csr(CVMX_MIO_FUS_RCMD))
01002            && read_cmd.s.pend)
01003         ;
01004     return read_cmd.s.dat;
01005 }
01006 
01007 /**
01008  * Read a single fuse bit
01009  *
01010  * @param node   Node number
01011  * @param fuse   Fuse number (0-1024)
01012  *
01013  * @return fuse value: 0 or 1
01014  */
01015 static inline int cvmx_fuse_read_node(uint8_t node, int fuse)
01016 {
01017     return (cvmx_fuse_read_byte_node(node, fuse >> 3) >> (fuse & 0x7)) & 1;
01018 }
01019 
01020 /**
01021  * Read a single fuse bit
01022  *
01023  * @param fuse   Fuse number (0-1024)
01024  *
01025  * @return fuse value: 0 or 1
01026  */
01027 static inline int cvmx_fuse_read(int fuse)
01028 {
01029     return (cvmx_fuse_read_byte(fuse >> 3) >> (fuse & 0x7)) & 1;
01030 }
01031 
01032 static inline uint64_t cvmx_mask_to_localaddr(uint64_t addr)
01033 {
01034     return (addr & 0xffffffffff);
01035 }
01036 
01037 static inline uint64_t cvmx_addr_on_node(uint64_t node, uint64_t addr)
01038 {
01039     return (node << 40) | cvmx_mask_to_localaddr(addr);
01040 }
01041 
01042 /**
01043  * Given a CSR address return the node number of that address
01044  *
01045  * @param addr  Address to extract node number from
01046  *
01047  * @return node number
01048  */
01049 static inline uint8_t cvmx_csr_addr_to_node(uint64_t addr)
01050 {
01051     return (addr >> CVMX_NODE_IO_SHIFT) & CVMX_NODE_MASK;
01052 }
01053 
01054 /**
01055  * Strip the node address bits from a CSR address
01056  *
01057  * @param addr  CSR address to strip the node bits from
01058  *
01059  * @return CSR address with the node bits set to zero
01060  */
01061 static inline uint64_t cvmx_csr_addr_strip_node(uint64_t addr)
01062 {
01063     return addr & ~((uint64_t)CVMX_NODE_MASK << CVMX_NODE_IO_SHIFT);
01064 }
